Award.AwardTitle: Motivations for Promotion and Prevention in Relationship Initiation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project applies contrasting motives to understand the complexities of relationship initiation and development. Specifically, the research examines when and why people attempt to initiate a relationship, who pursues the initiation, how rapidly the relationship develops, and the trajectory it takes as it becomes more established. Given the importance of relationships and lasting connections to well-being, research in this area has sought to develop a better understanding of how people establish meaningful social connections and transition from initial attraction, to affiliation, to stable and interdependent relationships. Although much is known about the qualities and circumstances that produce attraction as well as the regulation of closeness and intimacy in already established relationships, very little is known about the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors involved in the transition from attraction to intimacy. The investigators of this project make predictions for people's behaviors in relationships that are associated with either promotion or prevention-oriented goals.

These predictions will be tested across seven studies that either measure or manipulate people's motivations for promotion or prevention and then assess their (a) perceptions of interest and the potential for social support from others, (b) intentions to initiate and pursue relationships, and (c) behaviors associated with such pursuit (e.g., conveyed attraction to and self-disclosure toward others). The studies will also analyze both short-term interactions between strangers and the more extended development of friendships or romantic partnerships. By studying these types of relationship processes, findings from this research could help to attenuate the problem of loneliness as well as facilitate social transitions following relocation, change of employment and divorce.

Intellectual Merit

Research has shown that happiness, well-being, and even health, are highly dependent upon the lasting connections people establish with others. Understanding how relationships begin, develop, and end is thus a central priority for psychological research. Whereas much has been learned about people’s initial attraction to one another, and about how partners maintain intimacy once a relationship has been established, the transition from attraction to intimacy remains largely unexplored. The sponsored research applied insights from studies of self-regulation to examine when, why, and how people initiate relationships, as well how these relationships unfold. Specifically, the project investigated how broad motivations for growth (promotion) versus motivations for security (prevention) initiate and direct specific processes of relationship development, including perceptions of being liked by others, conveying one’s attraction to others, and actively pursuing relationship formation.

 

The major activities of this project involved conducting several different types of studies. Three studies placed participants in live interactions with peers who were or were not trained to convey romantic interest, and assessed the reciprocal interest conveyed by the participant. Another study brought two participants together for a one-hour "blind date" and assessed their romantic interest and level of intimacy before and after that date. The final study recorded the experiences of first-year college students for six months, beginning from the first few weeks after their arrival on campus, and assessed the friendships and romantic relationships they formed. Another major activity of the project was further analysis of an existing data set from a speed dating event, in which participants interacted with up to 12 potential romantic partners for four minutes each in a round-robin fashion and reported their impressions of these potential partners.

 

In all of these activities, the specific objectives were to investigate how people's broad motivations affect their judgments of and behavior toward potential relationship partners. Much previous research has shown that individuals focused on motivations for promotion tend to adopt eager strategies of goal pursuit that involve seeking all possible opportunities for gain, even at the risk of error and loss. In contrast, individuals focused on motivations for prevention tend to adopt vigilant strategies of goal pursuit that involve protecting against losses, even at the risk of forgoing opportunities for gain. Thus, the primary hypotheses tested in the sponsored research were that, when promotion-focused, people will be more likely to (a) eagerly perceive romantic interest from someone else, (b) eagerly perceive that this person will be responsive during an interaction, and, therefore, (c) display interest in and pursue a relationship with this person than when prevention-focused.

 

Results consistently provided good support for these hypotheses. The stronger people’s motivations for promotion, the more they did indeed view others as conveying greater romantic interest both when judging hypothetical scenarios and when forming expectations about upcoming interactions.
